title.narrative: OGB - Reg. SADCC Progr Dev South Africa

description.narrative:
Oxfam in South Africa (OGB) submitted a proposal for 60.000 euro to: • ensure that the SADC National Committee in South Africa is fully functional. • The requisite number of ratifications are received to bring into force the SADC Protocol on Facilitation of Free Movement of People • To build the capacity of civil society organisations (CSOs) and ordinary residents in South Africa in understanding the workings of SADC and its institutions and how to make input therein. • Review of the SADC Finance and Investment Protocol to mainstream mandatory reporting of extractive industry payments and other key business information on a country-by-country, and project by project basis (MoU on tax and related matters). ON will make a contribution of 55.000 eur for one year and the balance will be covered by OiSA. Throughout this action, Oxfam will seek to build the collective capacity of CSOs working at both national and SADC region levels in particular on issues related to human security, free movement of people, transparency in extractives and public policies geared towards tackling poverty and inequality as well as stimulating participatory democracy. Specifically, the extractives component will be led by Oxfam GB, working in partnership with African Monitor, EJN and where relevant Bench marks foundation. OiSA will enter into partnership agreement with CoRMSA for the implementation activities related to the protocol on regional integration and development through the ratification, domestication and implementation of the SADC Protocol on the Facilitation of Movement of Persons. Activities related to capacity building, monitoring and evaluation will be implemented by Oxfam GB.
Key measurable deliverables: • CSO SADC Migration Policy document that will inform engagement with South Africa and diplomatic representatives • 2000+ signatures in support of the SADC We Want Campaign • Training Manual on how to engage with SADC • An inclusive SADC National Committee in South Africa • Position Paper of extension of regularisation (Special Dispensation) to another SADC country’s nationals in addition to Zimbabweans.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam’s work in South Africa began in 1956 with a grant of £250 to feed poor children in the country. These feeding programmes continued throughout the 1960s, with more than £90,000 allocated to various agencies involved in a number of feeding projects. Today they work with partners and allies to campaign and advocate for poor and marginalised people’s rights to be recognised and enforced. They work very closely with South African civil society organisations, helping them make their voices heard. Oxfam also provides financial support to a number of partner organisations in the country. These organisations work with communities and groups to: • secure immigrants’ rights • achieve equitable health care for all South Africans • promote dignity and support for people affected by HIV and AIDS • ensure equality for all women and men • improve poor people’s ability to contribute to the growing economy and reap the benefits. Main programs include: GOVERNANCE: DOMESTIC RESOURCE MOBILISATION, TAX AND FISCAL POLICIES Calling for tax justice and a pro-poor tax regime in South Africa, Oxfam works with strategic partners to launch lobby, advocacy and campaign actions around social policies, tax policies and domestic resources mobilisation. By fostering social bargaining, citizen engagement in the political process and encouraging governments’ responsiveness, accountability and efficiency, Oxfam seeks to ensure that the poor have a voice in decision making around tax policies. SMALL-SCALE PRODUCERS Oxfam works with South African NGOs and small-scale producers on agricultural developmental and land-related policies to ensure government and the public fully understand the significant role small-scale producers play in the food production cycle. Ultimately, Oxfam works to assist small scale producers with getting the support they require from decision makers in government, the private sector and civil society. CLIMATE CHANGE Oxfam works with partners to call for policy and practices that include input from women small-scale farmers to ensure rural communities are better supported to adapt to climate change and benefit from pro-poor low carbon development.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
